docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''For Those Who Can Afford It, Old-Style Medicine Returns'' (front page, March 17): Dr. Herbert Rubin and others like him have adopted a sane response to an insane system and should be applauded. They no longer waste time, money and manpower on insurance hassles. They are truly free to act in the patient's best interest, and can protect confidentiality.
docs.abstract: Richard Amerling letter comments on March 17 article on doctors who have dropped out of managed-care system in effort to provide more effective care for patients (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bard College in Dutchess County, which primarily teaches the liberal arts to undergraduates, said yesterday that it would begin borrowing science professors from Rockefeller University in Manhattan and would also send its students to Rockefeller to take classes. Bard appears to be the primary beneficiary of the arrangement, but Rockefeller, a premier science institution that caters exclusively to candidates for doctoral degrees, says its teachers and students will benefit from teaching Bard's undergraduates. In addition, Rockefeller students will broaden their graduate experience by hearing guest lectures from visiting Bard professors like the authors Richard Ford and Chinua Achebe.

headline.main: Bard College Will Borrow Rockefeller U. Professors to Teach Science

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, William O. Daniel's doctor adopted a new policy. No longer would the doctor, Herbert Rubin of Beverly Hills, Calif., accept payments from health maintenance organizations. No longer would he be on insurance companies' preferred provider lists. No longer would he even accept Medicare. From then on, if you wanted to see Dr. Rubin, you paid cash. ''That was frightening to me,'' said Mr. Daniel, a 72-year-old retired insurance salesman who lives in Hollywood. Reluctantly, he changed doctors. But, he said, his new doctor's waiting room was always crowded and the doctor seemed pressed for time. ''I had to get out my symptoms in about 20 seconds or he would start interrupting me,'' Mr. Daniel said. ''Then I would have to wait while he saw more patients and then got back to me.''

headline.main: For Those Who Can Afford It, Old-Style Medicine Returns

docs.abstract: Growing number of doctors have severed their ties to health maintenance orgns and insurance companies; in return for cash payments, doctors offer a lavish level of service--uncrowded waiting rooms, long, uninterrupted office visits, and an office staff that knows the patients; several years after Pres Clinton's failed effort to remake health care in America, health care market is remaking itself; for those with insurance or the money to pay for health care, there is evolving a two-tiered system; one tier is made up of doctors who have cut their prices at insistence of health insurers and who make up for reduced prices by increasing their volume, seeing more patients per hour; other tier is made up of doctors who offer time and attention, but at a cost; example cited of Dr Herbert Rubin, Beverly Hills physician who swore off accepting insurance, and one of his patients, William O Daniel; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INVENTING AL GORE A Biography By Bill Turque Illustrated. 448 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $25. In outline at least the Al Gore who emerges from Bill Turque's thoughtful new biography will be familiar to anyone who has followed print and television coverage of his vice presidency and the opening rounds of the 2000 campaign: a cautious politician who frequently seems programmed, despite labored efforts to retool his image with a ''game-show host wardrobe'' and a high-decibel congeniality; an often awkward man whose Boy Scout persona belies a slashing braggadocio and a Clintonesque taste for double-talk and self-promotion. What Mr. Turque, a Washington correspondent for Newsweek, has done in ''Inventing Al Gore'' is to amplify this portrait of the vice president with lots of details and a carefully considered appraisal of his career. There isn't much that's actually new in this book, save the claim of two former friends that Mr. Gore was an ''enthusiastic recreational user'' of marijuana through the early 1970's, which was already cited in Newsweek's recent excerpt from this book.

headline.main: Toting the Merit Badges of a Boy Scout Candidate

docs.lead_paragraph: In taking their first step toward a federal budget for next year, House Republicans were left today in the awkward position of backing a smaller tax cut than their party's presumptive presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush. The tax and spending blueprint, passed by the House Budget Committee on a near party-line vote of 23 to 18, would provide more money for the Pentagon and education, freeze or cut many other programs and set aside at least $150 billion and perhaps as much as $250 billion for tax cuts over five years starting in 2001.

headline.main: Republicans Can't Match Bush's Plan for Tax Cuts

docs.abstract: House Republicans, in taking their first step toward federal budget for next year, are left in awkward position of backing smaller tax cut than their party's presumptive presidential nominee, Gov George W Bush; House Budget Committee votes 23 to 18 to set aside at least $150 billion and perhaps as much as $250 billion for tax cuts over five years starting in 2001; Bush's plan calls for tax cut of $483 billion over five years starting in 2002 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to file complaints today contending that four drug companies harmed consumers when they made agreements that delayed the sale of low-cost generic drugs, according to lawyers and executives briefed on the matter. The expected civil actions will be the first to come from a continuing investigation by the commission into the growing number of deals between companies that make brand-name drugs and competitors that are developing cheaper, generic forms of popular medications. Under the agreements, the brand-name company pays the generic company not to sell the lower-cost drug. As a result, consumers pay hundreds of millions of dollars more than they would if the cheaper drug were available.

headline.main: F.T.C. Expected to File Complaints Over Generic Drug Delays

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission is expected to file civil complaints contending that four drug companies harmed consumers when they made agreements that delayed sale of low-cost generic drugs; Andrx Corp says commission is expected to file case against it and Aventis, created with merger of Hoechst AG and Rhone-Poulenc SA, over 1997 agreement between Andrx and Hoechst; FTC is also expected to settle charges with Abbott Laboratories and Geneva Pharmaceuticals, generic drug company owned by Novartis (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Regulators in New York State, the nation's largest banking center and an industry pace setter, are devising new rules to crack down on lenders who impose exorbitant fees that force countless homeowners into foreclosure and bankruptcy. The abuses at issue are the underbelly of the lucrative $280 billion national market in loans for people with limited income or poor credit histories, so-called subprime borrowers. Although such loans charge higher interest rates, they have been a godsend to many people who otherwise might not get financing.

headline.main: New York Planning Crackdown On Excessive Home Loan Fees

docs.abstract: New York State regulators are devising new rules to crack down on lenders who impose exorbitant fees that force countless homeowners into foreclosure and bankruptcy; abuses at issue are underbelly of lucrative $280 billion national market in loans for people with limited income or poor credit histories; New York State Banking Board is flexing its powers to license and oversee mortgage bankers and brokers because action on issue is stalled in Congress; Gov George E Pataki ordered board to take up issue last year after investigation of major lender, Delta Funding, by Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the clearest sign that big money is becoming a dominant issue in the Democratic race for Senate, Jon S. Corzine today unveiled the first two television commercials of what is likely to be the most expensive campaign in New Jersey political history, and his opponent immediately charged that he was trying to buy the election. Mr. Corzine, a newcomer to politics who made hundreds of millions of dollars as co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, will begin running his two commercials on Wednesday, fully 12 weeks before the June 6 primary, in which he faces former Gov. Jim Florio.

headline.main: Corzine Joins Senate Battle With Flurry of New Ads

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 U.S. Releases in Full Its Trade Pact with China Responding to Congressional pressure, the Clinton administration declassified and released in full the trade agreement it reached with China last year. The 250-page document enshrines China's commitment to allow capitalism to spread.
